inference:
The cylinder has a radius of 4 and a height of 12.
The volume of a cylinder is given by $V = \pi r^2 h$.
The volume of the cylinder is $V_{cylinder} = \pi (4^2)(12) = 192\pi$.

The cone has a radius of 4 and a height of 6.
The volume of a cone is given by $V = \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2 h$.
The volume of the cone is $V_{cone} = \frac{1}{3}\pi (4^2)(6) = \frac{1}{3}\pi (16)(6) = 32\pi$.

The ratio of the volume of the cone to the volume of the cylinder is $\frac{V_{cone}}{V_{cylinder}} = \frac{32\pi}{192\pi} = \frac{32}{192} = \frac{1}{6}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$
ground_truth: The volume of a cone with radius $r$ and height $h$ is $(1/3) \pi r^2 h$; the volume of a cylinder with similar dimensions is $\pi r^2 h$.  The cone has the same radius as the cylinder and half the height, so it has $1/3$ the volume of half the cylinder and thus has $1/2\cdot 1/3 = 1/6$ the volume of the whole cylinder.  Hence the desired ratio is $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$.

The volume of the cone is $V_{cone} = \frac{1}{3}\pi (4^2)(6) = \frac{1}{3}\pi (16)(6) = 32\pi$.

The ratio of the volume of the cone to the volume of the cylinder is $\frac{V_{cone}}{V_{cylinder}} = \frac{32\pi}{192\pi} = \frac{32}{192} = \frac{1}{6}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1}{6}}$
